Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate several key problems in algebraic geometry and related areas of mathematics. Algebraic geometry is the study of solutions to polynomial equations; it has many applications in other areas of mathematics and other sciences. The project will focus on algebraic transformations over arbitrary fields, which has potential for practical application in computer science. The research involves graduate students and postdoctoral researchers at the University of Missouri.

This project is research in the areas of commutative algebra, algebraic geometry, valuation theory, and singularity theory. The problems that are being investigated are in four basic areas: Asymptotic multiplicities and Hilbert polynomials of graded families of ideals in a local ring, understanding better the cone of effective divisors modulo numerical equivalence (inradius, outradius and volume), toroidalization of morphisms (after blowing up nonsingular subvarieties make a morphism locally have a monomial like structure) and ramification, the defect and local uniformization. This last part involves better understanding ramification along a valuation in positive characteristic, with a view towards resolution of singularities.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was on research in Commutative Algebra and Algebraic Geometry within the field of Mathematics. Published research was performed, finding new results in asymptotic properties of ideals and on the structure of associated graded rings along a valuation. 

A very general structure theorem was found, showing that complex and real analytic mappings can be modified by very simple transformations (monoidal transformations) to become monomial, the simplest possible local structure. The construction is by an algorithm, and has the potential for practical application in engineering.

Three PhD students have been supported by the project. The PI has coorganized an international workshop in Oberwolfach, Germany, and cooraganized conferences in Osaka, Japan and Montreal, Canada during the time of this project. The PI was also a coorganizer of a KUMUNU conference which was held during  the time of this grant. The KUMUNU conferece was held at the University of Missouri, Columbia, as a rotating conference between the Universities of Kansas, Missouri and Nebraska. It features talks by leading researchers in Commutative Algebra and is attended mostly by graduate students and PostDocs at Midwest universities. The PI is completing a graduate textbook in Algebraic Geometry based on courses that he has given at the University of Missouri.


Last Modified: 08/08/2017
Modified by: Steven D Cutkosky
